g.text: The user is already logged in.
Up to your dApp but as the user is logged
in on your dApp side you probably want to
Get the encrypted key info for the user:
Makes sure the stored auth token matches the one sending in before returning the encrypted info
If you are not using node as your backend the github\readme explains what this method does so you can
write it in the language your using.
If false do not carry on and return
and 4xx http code back to your client.
(Up to your dApp if you wanted to put some
The signature is a signed hash of the encrypted
private key + iv signed with your ethereum private key
As you have this signature here you in theory can
verify the ethereum address is owned by this user.
You can add more authentication in here like a
jwt token or something along those lines but that
is up to you to decide depending on your dApps
The signature is a signed hash of the encrypted
private key + iv signed with your ethereum private key
If you are not using node as your backend the github\readme explains what this method does so you can
write it in the language your using.
If false do not carry on and return
and 4xx http code back to your client.
This returns a random salt and the server authentication hash
If you are not using node as your backend the github\readme explains what this method does so you can
write it in the language your using.
Replace in db mapped to username and point to the New_Username
- Don't forget your ethereum address (already exists on your db)
and private key to do any signing on the client
